feed.title: RSS Feed â€¢ elva
feed.subtitle: A multilingual, clean, green, 11ty starter theme

entry.title: Getting started
entry.content:
Make a directory and navigate to it:

mkdir my-site-name
cd my-site-name

Clone the elva repository:

git clone https://github.com/scottsweb/elva.git .

Install dependencies:

npm install

Run Eleventy for site development. View the site at http://localhost:8081:

npm run dev

Generate a production-ready build to the dist folder:

npm run build:prod

You can also set the environment variable NODE_ENV=production in your hosting control panel and use npm run build as with previous versions of elva.

To use Front Matter CMS, install VSCodium or Visual Studio Code and enable the extension (if it doesnâ€™t enable automatically). It will open each time you launch your project.

entry.title: Importing content
entry.content:
You can import content into elva using 11ty import. It supports importing content from WordPress, RSS/Atom, Bluesky, the Fediverse and YouTube.

Here are some examples of how to use it with elva:

WordPress

Run the following command from within the elva directory in Terminal:

# Import *all* posts from the WordPress API
# Draft posts available when WORDPRESS_USERNAME and WORDPRESS_PASSWORD environment
# variables are supplied, read more: https://www.11ty.dev/docs/environment-vars/

npx @11ty/import wordpress https://blog.fontawesome.com --output=content/en/posts/ 

# Useful flags when testing:
# --dryrun --assetrefs=disabled --within=7d
Note: Images are imported alongside the markdown. You may need to move assets to a more suitable folder (/content/assets/) or update the references to your images.

Fediverse

Run the following command from within the elva directory in Terminal:

# Import recent Mastodon posts (via RSS)

npx @11ty/import fediverse eleventy@fosstodon.org --output=content/en/toots/

# Useful flags when testing:
# --dryrun --assetrefs=disabled --within=7d

Atom Feeds

Run the following command from within the elva directory in Terminal:

# Import Atom feed posts

npx @11ty/import atom https://www.11ty.dev/blog/feed.xml --output=content/en/posts/ 

# Import GitHub releases (via Atom)

npx @11ty/import atom https://github.com/11ty/eleventy/releases.atom --output=content/en/releases/

# Useful flags when testing:
# --dryrun --assetrefs=disabled --within=7d

You can see more examples in the official documentation.

entry.title: Front matter
entry.content:
---
layout: page
title: Main page title, heading level one
date: 2023-08-04
modified: 2023-08-04
thumbnail: /assets/img/test.jpg
thumbnailDescription: An alt text description for the thumbnail image
tags: 'page-demo'
draft: true
eleventyExcludeFromCollections: true
seo:
  title: Custom title (defaults to title)
  description: SEO description
  slug: mmm-slugs
  changeFrequency: daily
  sitemapPriority: '1.0'
  excludeFromSitemap: true
  noIndex: true
---
  • layout â€” Page layout for the page. Default is post for posts and page for pages.
  • title â€” The title of the current page.
  • date â€” Published date. You can set special values here like Last Modified.
  • modifed â€” Modified date.
  • thumbnail â€” Relative path to thumbnail / opengraph image. Size 1200px x 630px.
  • thumbnailDescription â€” Alt text for thumbnail.
  • tags â€“ Tags are currently used for custom body classes.
  • draft â€” Draft pages will appear locally and on staging but not in production.
  • eleventyExcludeFromCollections â€” Hide from 11ty collections.
  • seo.title â€” Set custom page title for search engines and opengraph.
  • seo.description â€” Set the page description for search engines and opengraph.
  • seo.slug â€” Set a new slug for the page that is different from the filename.
  • seo.changeFrequency â€” How often does this page change?
  • seo.sitemapPriority â€” The priority of this URL relative to other URLs on your site.
  • seo.excludeFromSitemap â€” Hide this page from your sitemap.xml.
  • seo.noIndex â€” Discourage search engine indexing.

Nearly all front matter is optional, except for titles (and dates for posts).

Fusce augue lacus, vestibulum efficitur tincidunt et, posuere sed sem. Etiam tortor lorem, vestibulum ac lectus vitae, feugiat egestas augue. Proin id suscipit mi.

Lists

Ordered

  1. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet

  2. Consectetur adipiscing elit

  3. Integer molestie lorem at massa

  4. You can use sequential numbersâ€¦

  5. â€¦or keep all the numbers as 1.

Start numbering with offset:

  1. foo
  2. bar

Unordered

  • Create a list by starting a line with +, -, or *
  • Sub-lists are made by indenting 2 spaces:
    • Marker character change forces new list start:
      • Ac tristique libero volutpat at
      • Facilisis in pretium nisl aliquet
      • Nulla volutpat aliquam velit
  • Very easy!

Notices and links
